sen.j: 稗田 阿礼 （ひえだ の あれ、生没年不詳。7世紀後半から8世紀初頭の人）は、『古事記』の編纂者として知られる人物である。
sen.e: HIEDA no Are (dates of birth and death unknown, who lived in the latter half of the 7th century through the beginning of the 8th century) was a person known to have compiled "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters).
HIEDA no Are (dates of birth and death unknown; lived in the latter half of the 7th century through the beginning of the 8th century) compiled "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters).

sen.e: Nothing has been exactly known about HIEDA no Are except that she was 'one of the compilers of Kojiki'.

sen.j: 同時代に編まれた『日本書紀』にもこの時代の事を記した『続日本紀』にも名前は出てこない。
sen.e: Her name does not appear in "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) which was compiled while Are was alive or "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued) which describe people and events of the period she lived.

sen.j: 『古事記』の序文によれば、天武天皇に舎人として仕えていた。
sen.e: According to the preface of "Kojiki", she served Emperor Tenmu as a toneri (a palace servant).
According to the preface of "Kojiki," Are served the Emperor Tenmu as a toneri (a palace servant).

sen.j: 一度目や耳にしたことは決して忘れなかったので、その記憶力の良さを見込まれて『帝紀』『旧辞』等の誦習を命ぜられた。
sen.e: As she never forgot things she once saw or heard, she was assigned to a job of memorizing "Tei-ki" (records of Emperor's family tree) and "Kyuji" (mythical tradition) for her incredible memory.

sen.j: 元明天皇の代、詔により太安万侶が阿礼の誦する所を筆録し、『古事記』を編んだ。
sen.e: In the era of Empress Genmei, Are recited from her memory one by one for O no Yasumaro who wrote them down on paper to compile "Kojiki" with command of the Emperor.

Debatable issues

sen.j: 「舎人」（とねり）といえば通常は男性であるが、民俗学者の柳田國男、神話学者の西郷信綱らは「稗田阿礼は女性である」とする説を唱えている。
sen.e: Normally, a 'toneri' refers to a male servant, but Kunio YANAGIDA, a folklorist, and Nobutsuna SAIGO, a mythologist, insist that 'HIEDA no Are was a woman'.
Normally, a 'toneri' refers to a male servant, but Kunio YANAGIDA, a folklorist, and Nobutsuna SAIGO, a mythologist, insisted that 'HIEDA no Are was a woman.'

sen.e: Normally, a 'toneri' refers to a male servant, but Kunio YANAGIDA, a folklorist, and Nobutsuna SAIGO, a mythologist, insisted that 'HIEDA no Are was a woman.'

sen.j: 稗田氏はアメノウズメを始祖とする猿女君（さるめのきみ）と同族であり、猿女君は巫女や女孺（にょうじゅ。下級女官）として朝廷に仕える一族であるというのがその根拠である。
sen.e: They argue that the HIEDA clan stemmed from the same family as the Sarume no kimi clan who had Amenouzume (goddess of entertainment) as its earliest ancestor and was assigned to serve the Imperial Court as miko (a shrine maiden) and nyoju (a court lady in a lower rank).

They argue that the Hieda clan stemmed from the same family as the Sarume no kimi clan who had Amenouzume (goddess of entertainment) as its earliest ancestor and was assigned to serve the Imperial Court as miko (a shrine maiden) and nyoju (a court lady in a lower rank).
sen.cmt: 「稗田氏」は個人名ではないので、全文字を大文字にする必要はないと判断しました。
sen.e: They argue that the Hieda clan stemmed from the same family as the Sarume no kimi clan who had Amenouzume (goddess of entertainment) as its earliest ancestor and was assigned to serve the Imperial Court as miko (a shrine maiden) and nyoju (a court lady in a lower rank).

sen.j: この説は長らく定説的に扱われて来たが、近年、古代史について「部外者として」精力的な研究をしている梅原猛は、『古事記』のその大胆で無遠慮な書き方や年齢などから推定して、稗田阿礼というのは実は藤原不比等の別名ではないかとの説を提出している。
sen.e: Although this theory has been treated as an established one for a long time, recently, Takeshi UMEHARA who studies ancient histories vigorously as what he calls himself 'an outsider' released his analysis on Are; considering both the bold and blunt writing style of "Kojiki" and the age of Are, the name 'HIEDA no Are' may be an alias of 'FUJIWARA no Fuhito (a male court noble and a powerful member of the Imperial Court)'.
